contextId.information: Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. A person becoming wise is spoken of as if wisdom would enter into a person's heart. AT: "you will gain much wisdom" or "you will learn how to be truly wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: wisdom will come into your heart

contextId.information: Here the heart represents a person's mind. The mind is spoken of as if it were a tablet upon which someone can write messages and commands. AT: "always remember them, as if you had written them permanently on a tablet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: write them on the tablet of your heart

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" represents the inner person. AT: "your whole being" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The writer speaks of his words preserving a person's life as if they were that person's life. AT: "my words give life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Possible meanings are 1) the word "lips" represents the words of the adulteress and the writer speaks of the attractiveness of her words as if her lips dripped with honey. AT: "the words of an adulteress are sweet, as if dripping with honey" or 2) the writer speaks of the allure of kissing the adulteress as if her lips dripped with honey. AT: "the kisses of an adulteress are sweet, as if her lips dripped with honey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the lips of an adulteress drip with honey

contextId.information: Here the word "path" represents the person's daily conduct and circumstances. AT: "Keep yourself far away from her" or "Stay away from her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Keep your path far away from her

contextId.information: The hand of the hunter refers to the hunter's control. AT: "from the control of the hunter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from the hand of the hunter

contextId.information: "what is beautiful about her" or "her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Being pierced by spears or arrows represents being killed. AT: "She has caused many people to fall dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: She has caused many people to fall down pierced

contextId.information: Here "mouth" represents a person who speaks. AT: "I speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "words" represent a message or teaching. Also, "mouth" stands for the person who is speaking. AT: "The things I teach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "life" represents the person's self. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This refers to animals whose meat will be eaten in the dinner that Wisdom will give. AT: "She has killed the animals for meat at dinner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Hand" represents the strength and ability of a person. AT: "A person unwilling to work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Lips" represent what a person says. AT: "tells lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Mouth" represents what a person says. AT: "From the righteous man's words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Out of the mouth of the righteous person

contextId.information: The "day of wrath" represents a specific event, such as the "day of Yahweh" or "judgment day" or "last days." AT: "A person's wealth will do him no good when God comes to judge." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Wealth is worthless on the day of wrath

contextId.information: "Mouth" represents what a person says. AT: "The words of the godless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"City" represents the community or people group. AT: "the people group prospers" or "the community becomes prosperous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Heart" represents the feelings, attitudes and motivations of a person. AT: "who have wicked thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

"Trapped" represents being caught in a snare or being tricked. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The wicked things an evil person says will trap him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: An evil person is trapped by his wicked talk

contextId.information: The phrase, "thrusts of a sword" represents cruel words that hurt another. AT: "What a person says without thinking can hurt as much as if he stabbed with a sword." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The words of one who speaks rashly are like the thrusts of a sword

contextId.information: "Lips" represents what a person says. AT: "A truthful person endures forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Hand" represents what a person does -- his works. AT: "Diligent people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "hears" represents listening in order to do it. AT: "A wise son obeys" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "mouth" represents what a person says. AT: "what he says" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The light stands for the influence of righteous people and is described as experiencing the human emotion of joy. This can also be expressed as a simile as it is by the UDB. AT: "The influence of righteous people produces joy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The light of righteous people rejoices

contextId.information: Here "hope" represents the thing a person hopes for. This can be stated in active form. AT: "When a person hopes for something but does not receive it for a very long time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The mouth and the lips both refer to what a person says. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the mouth of ... the lips of

contextId.information: The word "way" represents the conduct of life of a person. AT: "his conduct" or "how he lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "inherit" represents having permanent possession of something.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "tongue" refers to speech. The writer speaks of the words of a person who says things that help and encourage others as if they were a tree that provides life-giving nourishment. AT: "Kind words are like a tree that gives life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A healing tongue is a tree of life

contextId.information: The vegetables represent a small meal with very little food. AT: "a small meal" or "very little food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here the word "heart" is a metonym for the mind and thoughts. This represents the person who thinks. AT: "The person who does right ponders what to say before he answers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The heart of the righteous person ponders before it answers

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" represents the person's mind and thoughts. AT: "A person makes plans in his mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The plans of the heart belong to a person

contextId.information: The word "eyes" is a metonym for the way a person thinks about right and wrong. The writer speaks of what a person does as if that person were walking down a path. AT: "A person thinks that everything he does is pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: All of a person's ways are pure in his own eyes

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" represents the mind and thoughts. The writer speaks of a person's actions as if the person were walking on a path. AT: "A person plans in his mind what he will do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In his heart a person plans out his way

contextId.information: Here the word "lips" is a metonym for what the king says. AT: "What a king says is an oracle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: An oracle is on the lips of a king

contextId.information: Here the word "heart" represents the mind and thoughts. AT: "The thoughts of a wise person gives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The heart of a wise person gives

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person's conduct or behavior as if it were a road on which the person is traveling. AT: "A person thinks that the way he is living is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: There is a way that seems right to a man

contextId.information: Here "quiet" refers to "peace." AT: "to have peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Both of these phrases refer to what a fool says. AT: "What a fool says ... by what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: A fool's mouth ... with his lips

contextId.information: Here the "heart" is used to refer to the "mind" to emphasize a person's desire. AT: "in a person's mind" or "that a person desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "strong drink" refers to a person who is drunk with strong drink. AT: "a person who is drunk with strong drink starts fights" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "bread" refers to food in general. AT: "Food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "eyes" is a metonym for the way a person thinks about right and wrong. The writer speaks of what a person does as if it that person were walking down a path. AT: "Every person thinks that what he does is good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Every person's way is right in his own eyes

contextId.information: The tongue is a metonym for the words a person uses the tongue to speak. AT: "speaking lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The eye is a metonym for seeing what other people need, and the "generous eye" not only sees but gives what the other people need. The eye is also a synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "generous person" or "person who is willing to give things to other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: one who has a generous eye

contextId.information: It is his own heart that the person wants to be pure. The heart is a synecdoche for the person. AT: "loves having a pure heart" or "wants to be pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "mouth" is a metonym for the words that come out of the mouth. The writer speaks of a person being unable to escape having people punish him for evil deeds as if that person had fallen into a hole someone had dug in the ground from which he could not escape. AT: "The words spoken by an adulteress will draw you in, and it will be as if you have fallen into a deep and dangerous pit" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The mouth of an adulteress is a deep pit

contextId.information: The word "heart" is a metonym for what a person thinks and decides to do. Possible meanings are 1) "pay careful attention" or 2) "trust me completely." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "the heart" represents the feelings or emotions of a person. AT: "make a person feel joyful" or "make a person glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the "heart" represents the person's feelings or emotions. AT: "make me feel joyful" or "make me glad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "his own eyes" represents his thoughts. AT: "be wise in his own thoughts" or "think he is wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: be wise in his own eyes

contextId.information: Here "blood" represents a person's life. To "shed blood" means to murder someone. AT: "he has killed someone" or "he has murdered someone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The tongue here represents speaking.  AT: "flatters him with words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"persuade the people of a city to cause trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "face" is a metonym for the ruler listening to people telling him what they want him to do and then doing it. AT: "Many people want their ruler to pay attention to them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Many are those who seek the face of the ruler

contextId.information: The phrase "in their own eyes" is a metonym for their opinion. AT: "believes they are pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: is pure in their own eyes

contextId.information: The act of opening her mouth is a metonym for speaking. The abstract noun "wisdom" can be translated as an adverb or an adjective. AT: "she speaks wisely" or "she speaks wise words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Possible meanings are 1) literally "stand up and" or 2) as a metonym, "actively." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
